full_text: Welcome to the Diagnoses and ICD-10 Codes demonstration. In this demonstration, Eileen Lang will add a doctor and a diagnosis to an existing claim. First, let's flip at the medical details screen. While an injury description can be the best estimate of a lay person, a diagnosis is a very specific matter that can only come from a medical provider. In particular, diagnoses come in the form of codes, called International Classification of Diseases, Tenth Revision, or ICD-10. ICD-10 codes, once entered, appear on the Summary Card of the Medical Details page. Eileen requested and has received the initial medical report. She will enter the doctor's information on the parties involved page, then enter the diagnosis. She clicks the New Contact button. And, from the drop-down list, selects Vendor. And then Doctor. The doctor's first name is Jack. And his last name is Booney Apodic. A tax ID is required for all vendors. For a contact to be associated with a claim, it must have at least one role on that claim. A role is generally associated with either an exposure or with a claim as a whole. In this case, the role is associated with the medical details exposure. There is a list of roles, which can be expanded by configuration. One of the listed roles is Other, which provides additional flexibility. In this case, the role is Doctor. Eileen saves the doctor's information. In a real implementation more data would be collected. Returning to the medical details exposure. Eileen selects the medical case management card. And clicks Edit. She adds the medical diagnosis. The ICD code on the diagnosis is I49.0. The code represents ventricular fibrillation and flutter. The provider name picker lists only medical personnel and organizations associated with either this exposure or the claim as a whole. Eileen selects Dr. Booney Apodic. Eileen saves her work. This concludes the demonstration of diagnoses and ICD-10 code.

First, let's flip at the medical details screen. While an injury description can be the best estimate of a lay person, a diagnosis is a very specific matter that can only come from a medical provider. In particular, diagnoses come in the form of codes, called International Classification of Diseases,

Tenth Revision, or ICD-10. ICD-10 codes, once entered, appear on the Summary Card of the Medical Details page. Eileen requested and has received the initial medical report. She will enter the doctor's information on the parties involved page, then enter the diagnosis. She clicks the New Contact button. And, from the drop-down list, selects Vendor. And then Doctor. The doctor's first name is Jack.
And his last name is Booney Apodic.
A tax ID is required for all vendors.
For a contact to be associated with a claim, it must have at least one role on that claim.
A role is generally associated with either an exposure or with a claim as a whole.
In this case, the role is associated with the medical details exposure.
There is a list of roles, which can be expanded by configuration.
One of the listed roles is Other, which provides additional flexibility.
In this case, the role is Doctor.
Eileen saves the doctor's information.
In a real implementation more data would be collected.
Returning to the medical details exposure.
Eileen selects the medical case management card.
And clicks Edit.
She adds the medical diagnosis.
The ICD code on the diagnosis is I49.0.
The code represents ventricular fibrillation and flutter.
The provider name picker lists only medical personnel and organizations associated with either this exposure or the claim as a whole.
Eileen selects Dr. Booney Apodic.
Eileen saves her work.
This concludes the demonstration of diagnoses and ICD-10 code.
